column2: Oh, Phoebe, are you still on hold? I was supposed to call my Dad back\nlike two hours ago.'
Oh, yeah, he clipped on, he said call him as soon as you get a chance,\nhe\xc2\x92s at Flimby\xc2\x92s.'
What\xc2\x92s Flimby\xc2\x92s?'
Oh, yeah, that\xc2\x92s the word I use when I can\xc2\x92t remember the real\nthing.'
Okay. Hang up! That\xc2\x92s it! Come on!'

No! Rachel, that\xc2\x92s what they want me to do. My warranty expires\ntomorrow, if I don\xc2\x92t get through, they\xc2\x92re not gonna fix my crappy, broken phone\nfor free! We cannot let them win! It\xc2\x92s us versus them!'
Ye-e-es!!'
(entering) Hey.'
Hey. '
Uh, listen I gotta double check for tickets tonight. Who-who got what?'
I had one.'
I need two. I\xc2\x92m bringing Pete. My boyfriend. I have a boyfriend\nnow!'
Two it is. Ross, how about you?'
Uh, yeah, I ah, I also need two.'
Really? Who\xc2\x92s number two?'
Who\xc2\x92s number two? One of the more difficult games sewer workers\nplay.'
Uh, no, it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s just this person.'
Like a date type (looks at Rachel) person?'
Yeah, kinda. It\xc2\x92s this woman from work. I hope that won\xc2\x92t be too\nweird. Will it, Rach?'
No. No, not at all, not at all. I actually was gonna bring someone\nmyself, so\xc2\x85'
But you said one.'
I meant, me plus one!'
Okay. (to Phoebe and Chandler) Did ah, you guys mean you plus one?'
All right, I\xc2\x92ll see you tonight.'
Okay.'
Okay, bye-bye!'
Bye!'
Bye-bye!'
Okay, I need a date! (runs to her bedroom)'
Oh, hey, you guys are finally gonna get to meet Kate!'
Oh!'
(to Chandler) And I ah, borrowed some of your cologne. I hope she likes\nit.'
Joey, what are you doing?! It\xc2\x92s never gonna happen, she\xc2\x92s\nseeing somebody.'
Yeah, and I don\xc2\x92t have any cologne.'
The green bottle next to the shaving cream.'
Oh! Worm medicine for the duck.'
(to Phoebe) Here you go. You can wear this. (hands her a sweater)'
Thanks!'
Uh-huh.'

Okay. (on phone) Ooh, I\xc2\x92m setting the phone down. (does so) But
I\xc2\x92m still here! Just don\xc2\x92t go anywhere I\xc2\x92m still here. (starts to put on
the sweater) Don\xc2\x92t-don\xc2\x92t switch or anything, \xc2\x91cause I\xc2\x92m, I\xc2\x92m
right here. (She has pulled the sweater over her head, but her head is stuck in a sleeve.)
Just one sec. One sec! One second!! (She is now frantically trying to get the sweater on,
as Monica returns from the bathroom.) Wait! One second! Just\xc2\x85'
Phoebe?'
What?! Monica, I\xc2\x92m scared!!'
All right. Honey, that\xc2\x92s-that\xc2\x92s a sleeve. Okay? '
Yeah.'
And! We also have speaker phone. (She turns on the speaker phone.)'
Please, stay on the line. Your call is important to us.'
Okay, wait, you gotta hang up \xc2\x91cause we\xc2\x92re gonna be late.'
Thank you for your patience, you\xc2\x92re the next caller.'
Yes!! Yes!! I\xc2\x92m the next caller! You were gonna have me hang up.'
(entering, carrying the chick and duck) Hey! Can you take a duck and a\nchick to the theatre? '
Of course not.'
No.'
Okay. I just wanted them to hear it from somebody else.'
Hey, hey Rach!'
Oh, hi!'
Hi!'
How are you? (She goes to kiss him on the cheek, but stops because of\nthe dates and pats him on the shoulder.)'
Good.'
Hey.'
So it\xc2\x92s looks like we\xc2\x92re the first ones here.'
Yeah, looks that way. First ones here! Wooo!!'
Yay!!'
Oh! Tommy, this is Ross. Ross, Tommy.'
Hey.'
Hey. Oh, I\xc2\x92m sorry, this is Cailin.'
And! Break!!'
Okay, uhh, I think I\xc2\x92m going to run to the ladies room.'
Okay.'
I\xc2\x92ll join you.'
I\xc2\x92ll get our seats.'
Okay. (The girls leave.) (to Tommy) So uh, well, this-this is uh, this is\nawkward.'
Yeah?'
Well y'know \xc2\x91cause Rachel and I used to go out."
Oh, I didn\xc2\x92t, I didn\xc2\x92t know that.'
Oh! Well then this is awkward. So what do you uh\xc2\x85'
I think we\xc2\x92re here.'
Oh! Yeah. '
Yeah.'
Okay. (sees two people sitting in their seats.) Uh, huh. Excuse me,\nI\xc2\x92m sorry, I-I think you may be in our seats.'
Umm, no, I don\xc2\x92t think so.'
Can-can we take a look at your ticket?'
Sure. (Hands him the ticket.)'
(looking at ticket) Yep! Yeah, see this says D-13, and uh\xc2\x85'
Oh, well I thought that ah\xc2\x85'

Oh, you thought, huh? Yeah, well that didn\xc2\x92t really work out too\nwell for you did it you idiot!! What are you?! A moron!! Huh?! It says D-13! Okay?!\nLook you\xc2\x92re surrounded by even numbers!! Did that give you some clue?!'
Uh, the usher told us to come\xc2\x85'

Oh! Oh! The usher must be right! What, with all that training they go\nthrough! Get out!! (They start to leave.) Here! (He throws him back his ticket.) (to Ross,\ncalmly) Hey man, you want the aisle?'
No, I\xc2\x92m good. (He sits down, stunned.)'
(seeing Joey) There he is!'
There\xc2\x92s our star!'
So, so, what\xc2\x92d ya think?'
Almost as good as that play with the two naked girls on the see-saw.'
I-I wasn\xc2\x92t in that.'
I know.'
(sees Kate) Oh-oh, hey-hey, Kate! Listen I want you to meet everybody.\nEverybody, this is Kate.'
Hi!'
(stepping in) Excuse me. Excuse me. (to Kate) Sweetheart! (Kisses\nher.) Come! (They leave.)'
So that\xc2\x92s the girl you like.'
Yeah.'
(drags Chandler over to buffet table) I\xc2\x92m telling you, this guy\nRachel is with is crazy! Okay? He viscously screamed at total strangers! I think he\xc2\x92s\nbaaad news!'
Wait a minute, wait a minute, you don\xc2\x92t like the guy\nRachel\xc2\x92s dating? Well, that\xc2\x92s odd.'
Oh, hey, Lauren. Uh, you guys this is, this is Kate\xc2\x92s understudy,\nLauren.'
Oh, hi!'
Hey.'
Hey. Gosh, you look soo familiar.'
Oh, yeah! I-I ran into you in the hallway in your building. It was right\nafter I slept with Joey. He dumped me the next day.'
So. How\xc2\x92d you guys meet?'
Well ah, the short version is, I ah pursued her for a couple of months,\nthen I gave her a check for 20,000 dollars, and she was mine.'
Yeah, and in the long version, I dump him for telling people the short\nversion.'
Joey, sweetheart, you were fabulous! '
Hey you guys, this is my agent, Estelle.'
How do you do. (to Rachel and Monica) Ooh, you two girls were\noutstanding! (to Joey) Did they have representation?'
No, they-they weren\xc2\x92t in the play.'
We\xc2\x92re not actors.'
Ooh, what a shame! Because with her face (points to Monica) and her\nchest (points to Rachel) I could really put something together.'
Could I borrow it?'
(to Ross) Hi! Remember me?'
Hi! Yeah! Tommy\xc2\x92s in line for the bathroom and someone just cut in\nfront of him, I think he\xc2\x92s gonna snap. (He\xc2\x92s watching very intently)'
Ross, I\xc2\x92m gonna go.'
Go? Why?'
I don\xc2\x92t know. Could be because I don\xc2\x92t feel like standing\naround all night waiting for some guy who may or may not scream.'
But-but Cailin, he definitely will scream.'
Good bye Ross.'
Uh, oh-ho bye.'

(entering carrying a newspaper) Here we go people! (starts reading
the review) Boxing Day! The Lucille Lortel Theatre, blah-la-la-la\xc2\x85 Ah-ha! Joey
Tribianni, gives an uneven performance, but Mr. Tribianni is not the worst thing in this
production.'
Yes!!! Ha-ha-ha!'

Kate Miller\xc2\x92s awkward and mannered portrayal is laughable.
(Kate walks away depressed.) Badda-badda-badda. Ah-ha! Here it is! The direction by
Marshal Talmant is\xc2\x85 (stops, reads it again, and throws down the paper in disgust)
Thank you, boys and girls, you\xc2\x92ve ruined my life. Please, stuff your talentless faces
with my Mother\xc2\x92s crab cakes! (starts to leave) Excuse me!!'
Anyone mind if I save this?'
Monica and Rachel's, Monica and Rachel are returning. Phoebe is still on\nhold.]"
Hey!'
Hey!'
Oh, is the play over?'
Yeah. Where were you?'
Thank you for your patience, you\xc2\x92re the next caller.'
You were the next caller five hours ago. You must be going crazy.'
Nah. I kept myself busy.'
Oh, okay, yeah. (to Monica) I put your stuff in her room, and her stuff\nin your room.'
Hey! Are you okay?'
Fabulous.'
Listen, drama critics they\xc2\x92re nothing but, but people who\ncouldn\xc2\x92t make it as actors. You know what you should do?'
Become a drama critic!'
(entering, drunk) I am hurt! (to Joey and Kate) A plague on both\nyour houses! (walks away)'
By the way, he dumped me tonight after he read my review.'
Oh, classy. '
Yep! I sure know how to pick \xc2\x91em, huh? Y'know I gave up a part on a\nsoap for this!"
Wow! Yeah I ah, I gave up a job too.'
Really. What?'
Uh, de-clawing cats. Hey, tell ya what. Let me walk you home. We\xc2\x92ll\nstop by every news stand and burn every copy of their Times and the Post.'
Why the Post?'
Oh, you didn\xc2\x92t see the Post?'
No. You?'
No. Why?'
(drunk) So you really think those newspapers are just jealous of me?'
Oh, absolutely! You\xc2\x92re talented and you\xc2\x92re good looking.'
Oh, you\xc2\x92re sweet and cute.'
I know! That\xc2\x92s why they trashed me!'
Whoa. Wait a minute, wait a minute.'
What?'
I, I don\xc2\x92t get you. I mean first, you hate me. Then you sleep with\nme. Then you want nothing to do with me, now you want me again.'
What? So you never went out with an actress before?'
Kate, do you even like me?'
Of course I do.'
Well so, how come you blew me off? Y'know? How come you were with him?"
I don\xc2\x92t know! I just, just do this! I-I always have to pick the like\nthe smartest guy, or-or the most talented guy\xc2\x85 Why can\xc2\x92t I just pick someone\nlike you?'
Thanks.'
You know what I mean. I mean like the sweetest guy. Joey, you\xc2\x92re just\nso, you\xc2\x92re so, so\xc2\x85 (She passes out and slumps against his shoulder.)'

(Checks to see if she\xc2\x92s drooling on his shirt.) Okay. Okay, okay,
hey. (Lays her down and covers her with a blanket.) There we go, let\xc2\x92s get your feet
up there. (Looks at her) Good night, Kate. Sweet dreams. (Picks up a garbage can) I\xc2\x92m
gonna put this can right here in case you have to hurl.'
Monica and Rachel's, the next morning, Phoebe is STILL on hold.]"
Please stay on the line. You\xc2\x92re call is very important to us.'
(entering from her bedroom) Pheebs, you\xc2\x92ve been up for 24 hours! Go\nto sleep, honey. Th-this isn\xc2\x92t healthy.'
No, no, I\xc2\x92m fine, and y\xc2\x92know why? \xc2\x91Cause of all the\nriboflavin.'
(entering, happily) Hey!'
Hey! Didn\xc2\x92t you have that outfit on last night?'
Yeah! I stayed at Kate\xc2\x92s, but ah, nothing happened. Hey, Pheebs,\nwhere were ya?'

I\xc2\x92m so, so, so sorry, Joey. I definitely am gonna see you\xc2\x92re\nplay. I swear you\xc2\x92re play is very important to us, thank you for your patience.\nYou\xc2\x92re play is the next play is the next play I\xc2\x92m gonna see.'
Anyway, how did it go with Kate?'

Oh, it was great! Yeah, I-I walked her home, and it was amazing how much\nwe connected, y'know? Then ah, then she passed out, but then she woke up. Yeah? And we\nstayed up all night talking, and now we\xc2\x92re like totally crazy about each other!"
Joey, you had the night! '
What?'
When two people finally realise their feelings for each other, and-and\nthey talk for hours, and they-they learn all about the other person!'
You-you think?'
Did you like learn about her family?'
Two brothers, one died!'
Yes!!'
Yeah?!'
Oh! (They hug, triumphantly.)'
(bringing Chandler a cup) This is from the woman at the bar.'
Oh-ho-ho-ho. '
Sorry. She thought you were somebody else.'
What time is it?'
One.'
One.'
Tommy\xc2\x92s supposed to be here soon, we\xc2\x92re going to lunch.'
Look. Look, I wasn\xc2\x92t going to say anything to you, but... All right,\nI don\xc2\x92t think you should be seeing Tommy anymore.'
You don\xc2\x92t?!'
No! The guy is mean. I mean really mean. I think you should stay away from\nhim.'
Umm, or, maybe, I should stay away from all men.'

No, it\xc2\x92s not just \xc2\x91cause I\xc2\x92m jealous. (Both Monica and
Chandler give him a \xc2\x91Come on\xc2\x92 look) I mean I\xc2\x92m not, I\xc2\x92m not, I\xc2\x92m
not jealous, okay? It\xc2\x92s\xc2\x85 Look, the guy, he screamed, he actually screamed at
this couple sitting in our seats.'
Yeah, and at the end of the play, he, he got up y'know, and he just\nstarted like, (claps his hands) banging his hands together!"
Okay, fine, fine. You don\xc2\x92t want to believe me? No, that\xc2\x92s fine.\n(starts to leave)'
We\xc2\x92re kidding!'
Ross, don\xc2\x92t. Ross!'
You don\xc2\x92t want to believe me, I\xc2\x92m Mr. Funny to you. Mr.\nFunny\xc2\x85 (turns around and almost spills his coffee on Tommy) '
Whoa!!'
Whoa, sorry Tommy.'
What\xc2\x92s in the cup, Ross?'
Umm\xc2\x85'
What is in the cup?!'
Okay, it\xc2\x92s coffee.'
Ice coffee? Tell me it\xc2\x92s ice coffee!'
It\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s hot\xc2\x85'
Hot coffee!!! You idiot!! You were gonna spill hot coffee all over me,\nhuh?!! What are you just some big, dumb, stupid, doofy idiot, with a doofy idiot hairdo,\nhuh?! Huh?! '
(not seeing Ross) What\xc2\x92s your favourite thing about summertime?'
Umm, going to the beach. When it stays light real late.'
Yeah\xc2\x85'
(entering, finished with yelling at Ross, who follows him in shell\nshocked) (happily) Hey!'
Tommyyyy! Say, what\xc2\x92s your favourite thing about summer?'
Ooh, I don\xc2\x92t know. Probably the smell of freshly cut grass.'
Ohh, that\xc2\x92s a good one.'
Sorry! Sorry, I\xc2\x92m late; sorry, I\xc2\x92m late! My duck and my chick\nand a fight, it-it was ugly.'
Look, we held the curtain for you buddy. Come on, let\xc2\x92s go!\nLet\xc2\x92s go!'
(answering the door) Vic! Where have you been, baby?!'
(surprised it\xc2\x92s Lauren) (hugs her) (whispering) Where\xc2\x92s Kate?'
(whispering) She got a job in L.A.'
(stunned) What?!'
I\xc2\x92ve been waiting up all night for ya. Where have you been? (Joey\ndoesn\xc2\x92t answer) Where have you been? Vic?!'
Oh, ahh, go to the window. I\xc2\x92m wanna run down to the truck and show\nyou something.'
(at the window, she\xc2\x92s looking down out of the window) What do you\ngot down there, Vic? What do you got under that tarp? '
(grabs the window from the outside and sticks his head in) (whispering)\nWhen is she leaving?'
(whispering) Tonight. What are you doing?'
(making like he is yelling up to the second floor) I\xc2\x92m coming up!'
Hey, mind if I use the phone?'
Oh, I\xc2\x85 (starts jabbering incoherently)'
Why don\xc2\x92t you use ours across the hall, \xc2\x91cause\nshe\xc2\x85has\xc2\x85problems.'
(coming out of the kitchen with a cup of coffee, almost running into\nTommy) Oh-ho, whoa! Sorry, Tommy. I almost spilled this hot coffee on you.'
Yeah, but you didn\xc2\x92t.'
No, but it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s hot!'
Ross, would you just stop it! It\xc2\x92s getting really old.'
I can\xc2\x92t believe no one believes me!'
I do, I believe you.'
You do Pheebs?'
Yeah. But I also believed her (points to the phone) when she said I was\nnext.'

(noticing the chick) Ooh, hey! Hey, there little fella. (picks up the
chick) Mr. Fuzzy-Man, how are you doing? (starts to pet him) Aww. (The chick poops on his
hand.) Eww! Oh! Eww! Gross! Idiot!! Stupid little, fuzzy, yellow creature!! Oh look at me,
I\xc2\x92m so cute, I\xc2\x92m a little chick who\xc2\x92s disgusting! God, you\xc2\x92re so
stupid, how are you not yet extinct!! (the duck wattles behind him and quacks) (to the
duck) Quack-quack, quack-quack!! What are you quacking about?! Dumb Donald Doo-Doo!! '
Step away from the duck.'
Ooh, sorry little Mr. Chic-A-Dee, sorry you went doody in my hand!\n(starts to walk out and stops) (to Rachel) Well, I guess we\xc2\x92re not going out anymore.\nWhaa!!!'
Joey!'
Hey!'
I\xc2\x92m soo glad I caught you, I couldn\xc2\x92t find you before.'
Wh-wh-what\xc2\x92s going on? Wh-what\xc2\x92s this about L.A.?'
They still want me for General Hospital.'
But, but wh-what about us?'
Last night was wonderful. But I-I can\xc2\x92t stay here just for you.'
Well, so, stay for the museums! '
I\xc2\x92m sorry.'
Joey, onstage!'
Well can you at least stay to the end of the play? I mean, I\xc2\x92ll go to\nthe airport with ya, I-I wanna say good bye.'
(yelling from onstage) Where are you Vic?'
Flight\xc2\x92s in an hour. I-I gotta go.'
Vic! Vic! Vic!!! '
(to Lauren) In a minute!!'
So this is it? Victor?'

Yeah, I guess it is. (sees Kate is watching, he turns Lauren so that he
can talk directly to Kate, but still look like he is talking to Lauren) Listen, I ah, I
gotta say good bye, and-and I gotta say it quick \xc2\x91cause this is killing me. One thing
you gotta know, is that I will never forget you. But, you\xc2\x92ve got things you have to
do now, and so do I. And so\xc2\x85 I\xc2\x92m gonna get on this spaceship, (smoke starts
pouring in from the ceiling, and a ladder comes down, with flashing, colored lights on the
side of it) and I\xc2\x92m gonna go to Blargon 7 in search of alternative fuels. But when I
return, 200 years from now, you\xc2\x92ll be long gone. But I won\xc2\x92t have aged at all.
(gets on the ladder) So you tell your great-great-granddaughter to look me up, because
Adrienne, baby, I\xc2\x92m gonna want to meet her. '
So long, Vic! (waving good bye as the ladder retracts)'
Phoebe, it\xc2\x92s been two days.'
Yeah, I know. Oh, good thing it\xc2\x92s one of those 801 numbers. Right?'
Phoebe, 800 is toll free, 801 is-is Utah.'

No, no, no, oh no-no-no, it\xc2\x92s has to be 800. (picks up the\ninstruction manual to check the phone number) \xc2\x91Cause all those big companies have 800\nnumbers, every one. (Finds the number) Yeah, every big Utah-based company has one.'
Phoe-be!!'
Sorry, I\xc2\x92m so sorry, I will pay you back.'
And yet, she\xc2\x92s still not hanging up the phone.'
Hang it up! Hang up the phone!!'
Fine! Fine! (slams the phone down, breaking it) Oh-oh!'
What?'
Well, I think I broke it. But that\xc2\x92s all right, here\xc2\x92s the\nnumber you can call.'
(sarcastic) Oh.'
